<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarGetInfo(osal_id_t var_id, OS_condvar_prop_t *condvar_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(condvar_prop);

    memset(condvar_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_condvar_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_condvar_table, token);

        strncpy(condvar_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(condvar_prop->name) - 1);
        condvar_prop->creator = record->creator;

        return_code = OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl(&token, condvar_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>

<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
    memset(condvar_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_condvar_prop_t));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The memset call uses sizeof(OS_condvar_prop_t) and the function parameter is typed as OS_condvar_prop_t *; therefore, assuming the caller provides a pointer to an object of that type (or larger), the memset will not access beyond the bounds. A violation could only occur if the caller incorrectly passes a pointer to a smaller object or an invalid/incorrectly cast pointer (e.g. a buffer smaller than sizeof(OS_condvar_prop_t)), but that would be a caller-side type/contract violation rather than a problem in this code fragment.
